title: Casual & Formal Ways to Say Youâ€™re Welcome (with Examples)

steps.title: â€œOf course.â€
steps.content: â€œOf course.â€ This friendly response makes it clear to your friends and family that your help and kindness are guaranteed. By saying â€œOf course,â€ youâ€™re telling them that they can expect favors or help from you because youâ€™re happy to support them. [1] X Research source Them : â€œThank you for grabbing me a coffee, too!â€ You : â€œOf course! I know how much you love iced lattes!â€

steps.title: â€œNo problem.â€
steps.content: â€œNo problem.â€ Responding to a friendâ€™s, â€œThank youâ€ with a cheerful â€œNo problemâ€ or â€œNot a problemâ€ means that the help you gave them didnâ€™t bother or inconvenience you. This is an especially great response to ease someoneâ€™s worry or guilt if they thought they were burdening you with a favor. For an even more casual response, say â€œNo probâ€ or â€œNo problemo!â€ [2] X Research source Them : â€œI canâ€™t thank you enough for picking up Chili from the dog groomers! You are a lifesaver.â€ You : â€œNo problem! I was already headed that way so it just took me a second to get him.â€ Note : Older adults can find â€œNo problemâ€ impolite or rude, as it can sound like the help they asked for was a problem for you (even though this phrase means the opposite). So, stick to saying it to your younger friends and family instead of your elders.

steps.title: â€œNo worriesâ€ or â€œDonâ€™t worry about it.â€
steps.content: â€œNo worriesâ€ or â€œDonâ€™t worry about it.â€ These phrases are friendly ways to let someone know that it wasnâ€™t difficult or bothersome for you to help them out. Youâ€™re telling them that what they asked wasnâ€™t a burden and in fact, you were happy to help! Responding with this phrase is another great way to make a friend or family member feel less embarrassed or uncomfortable about asking you for help. Them : â€œThank you for going to the store and getting more ice when we ran out! I feel bad that I asked you to go late at night.â€ You : â€œNo worries at all! Iâ€™m glad I could help.â€

steps.title: â€œAbsolutely.â€
steps.content: â€œAbsolutely.â€ Saying â€œAbsolutelyâ€ in place of â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ is a cheerful way to tell your loved ones that it makes you happy to do them favors, give them gifts, or help them out. It also conveys that it wasnâ€™t bothersome or difficult for you to support or assist themâ€”if anything, it was your pleasure to help them. [3] X Research source Them : â€œWow, I canâ€™t believe you got me such a thoughtful gift! I love it, thank you so much!â€ You : â€œAbsolutely! I know how much you love this author and when I saw they signed your favorite book, I had to get it for you!â€

steps.title: â€œAnytime.â€
steps.content: â€œAnytime.â€ This warm and heartfelt response to a loved oneâ€™s, â€œThank youâ€ lets them know that they can always rely on your help. Saying, â€œAnytimeâ€ also makes it clear that you were glad to support them and would do it again in a heartbeat, which can make them more comfortable if they were worried about troubling you. [4] X Research source Them : â€œThank you for giving me a ride to school! I donâ€™t know what Iâ€™d do without you.â€ You : â€œAnytime! I donâ€™t mind picking you up and I love the company.â€

steps.title: â€œSure thing.â€
steps.content: â€œSure thing.â€ â€œSure thingâ€ is short for, â€œIt is a sure thing that I would help you.â€ This enthusiastic response is a very casual way to let a friend know that they can trust you to support them. In other words, your help is guaranteed because helping them doesnâ€™t bother you at all! Them : â€œIâ€™m so grateful you could help me move my furniture after Don bailed on me.â€ You : â€œSure thing! You can always count on me for help.â€

steps.title: â€œYou bet.â€
steps.content: â€œYou bet.â€ â€œYou betâ€ is another very informal way to say, â€œYouâ€™re welcome.â€ This phrase is short for, â€œYou can bet on my helpâ€ and means that your loved ones can always expect you to support them or assist them with favors. If your friends are worried about burdening you, saying â€œYou betâ€ can reassure them that your help wasnâ€™t an inconvenience. Them : â€œAw, did you get pizza for dinner? You rock, thanks a bunch!â€ You : â€œYou bet! I know you had a bad week, so I thought this would cheer you up!â€

steps.title: â€œYepâ€ or â€œYou got it.â€
steps.content: â€œYepâ€ or â€œYou got it.â€ Enthusiastic and affirmative phrases like â€œYep,â€ â€œYup,â€ â€œSure,â€ â€œTotally,â€ and â€œYou got itâ€ are super casual ways to say, â€œYouâ€™re welcome.â€ These quick phrases acknowledge your friendâ€™s gratitude and make it clear that your help wasnâ€™t a big deal. You can even say a cheerful â€œMm-hmmâ€ or â€œUh-huhâ€ or if youâ€™re texting, send a thumbs-up ğŸ‘ emoji . [5] X Research source Them : â€œThanks for taking out the trash! Iâ€™ve been meaning to do that but Iâ€™ve been so busy.â€ You : â€œYou got it!â€

steps.title: â€œDonâ€™t mention it.â€
steps.content: â€œDonâ€™t mention it.â€ When someone thanks you for doing something that you thought was very minor or insignificant, say â€œDonâ€™t mention it.â€ This is a humble and polite way to say that their gratitude isnâ€™t necessaryâ€”what you did wasnâ€™t a big deal and didnâ€™t inconvenience you at all. Them : â€œWow, I canâ€™t believe you got me a ticket for the concert on Friday! I thought the show was sold out! You are the best!â€ You : â€œAw, donâ€™t mention it! Iâ€™m glad we get to go together now!â€

steps.title: â€œIt was nothing.â€
steps.content: â€œIt was nothing.â€ â€œIt was nothingâ€ is another humble and polite alternative to â€œYouâ€™re welcome.â€ Like â€œDonâ€™t mention it,â€ this phrase also means that your help or support wasnâ€™t a big deal or significant enough to get a â€œThank youâ€ from your friend. For an even more casual response, say, â€œNo biggieâ€ or â€œNo sweat.â€ [6] X Research source Them : â€œThank you so much for being able to watch Harper last minute! She loved getting to spend time with her aunt!â€ You : â€œOf course, it was nothing! You know I love babysitting my favorite niece!â€

steps.title: â€œItâ€™s the least I can do.â€
steps.content: â€œItâ€™s the least I can do.â€ â€œItâ€™s the least I can doâ€ is a friendly response to a loved oneâ€™s â€œThank youâ€ when you feel like your help wasnâ€™t actually that noteworthy or significant. This is a sweet way to reassure your friend that helping them wasnâ€™t an intrusion and that you are glad to assist them. You might even say this if you thought you couldâ€™ve helped them even more. [7] X Research source Them : â€œIâ€™m so grateful that you could come over early and help me set up for the party. Everyone said it was a blast!â€ You : â€œReally, itâ€™s the least I could do! Thanks for throwing such a fun party!â€

steps.title: â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™d do the same for me.â€
steps.content: â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™d do the same for me.â€ If you and a friend support one another often, this phrase is a great alternative to a simple â€œYouâ€™re welcome.â€ This phrase acknowledges your friendâ€™s appreciation and expresses your happiness to help them out. It also communicates that they didnâ€™t ask you to do something inconvenient or bothersome, as theyâ€™d be glad to do the same favor for you. Them : â€œI canâ€™t thank you enough for taking care of me while I was sick. Iâ€™m not sure how to pay you back for your kindness.â€ You : â€œI know youâ€™d do the same for me. So, donâ€™t worry about it. Iâ€™m just glad youâ€™re feeling better!â€

steps.title: â€œJust returning the favor.â€
steps.content: â€œJust returning the favor.â€ Use this phrase in place of â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ when you helped out someone who recently did you a favor. This is a friendly way to accept their gratitude while showing them that what they asked of you wasnâ€™t an imposition or inconvenience. It also expresses your thanks for their previous help to you! [8] X Research source Them : â€œThanks so much for watering my plants while I was on vacation! They look just as happy and healthy as when I left.â€ You : â€œHey, just returning the favor! You kept my plants alive when I was gone last month.â€

steps.title: â€œThank you.â€
steps.content: â€œThank you .â€ If someone is thanking you but you feel like they did you a favor, itâ€™s perfectly acceptable to say â€œThank youâ€ back instead of â€œYouâ€™re welcome.â€ Simply emphasize the â€œyouâ€ to show them that youâ€™re the one who should be thanking them! Them : â€œThank you for coming to visit! I loved having you stay at my new apartment. It was so fun to show you around the city!â€ You : â€œNo, thank you . I appreciate you letting me stay and being such a great host! Plus, I got to hang out with you!â€

steps.title: â€œMy pleasure.â€
steps.content: â€œMy pleasure.â€ â€œMy pleasureâ€ is a more formal way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ thatâ€™s acceptable to use with supervisors, colleagues, customers, and other people you have a professional relationship with. This pleasant phrase communicates that you enjoyed helping out the person, which can make them feel more comfortable asking you for help in the future. [9] X Research source Them : â€œThank you for getting refreshments for the meeting today! I canâ€™t believe I forgot.â€ You : â€œMy pleasure. Iâ€™m glad the meeting went well!â€

steps.title: â€œIâ€™m pleased to be of assistance.â€
steps.content: â€œIâ€™m pleased to be of assistance.â€ Use this very formal and flattering phrase to let your boss, coworkers, or customers know that youâ€™re genuinely happy to help them out. â€œIâ€™m pleased to be of assistanceâ€ simultaneously acknowledges their gratitude for what you did and expresses your desire to help them again in the future. Them : â€œI canâ€™t thank you enough for working late and getting the proposal submitted. If you hadnâ€™t stepped in, we would've missed the deadline!â€ You : â€œIâ€™m pleased to be of assistance. If you need my help again in the future, just let me know.â€

steps.title: â€œIâ€™m happy to help.â€
steps.content: â€œIâ€™m happy to help.â€ This polite phrase is a common alternative for â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in the business world. It is a warm way to communicate your willingness and desire to support your colleagues or help clients. As a plus, it can boost your reputation for being a helpful employee and lead to more opportunities in your career. [10] X Research source Them : â€œThanks for sending me those reports so quickly!â€ You : â€œIâ€™m happy to help!â€

steps.title: â€œItâ€™s always a pleasure to help out.â€
steps.content: â€œItâ€™s always a pleasure to help out.â€ This warm expression is a slightly more formal version of â€œIâ€™m happy to help.â€ Itâ€™s a thoughtful way to let professional colleagues or people you donâ€™t know very well that you enjoyed assisting them with a task or favor and that it didnâ€™t burden you in any way. Them : â€œI so appreciate you taking the time to help me with this last-minute deadline.â€ You : â€œItâ€™s always a pleasure to help out.â€

steps.title: â€œCertainly.â€
steps.content: â€œCertainly.â€ â€œCertainlyâ€ is a more formal alternative to phrases like â€œOf courseâ€ and â€œSure thing.â€ Like those expressions, â€œCertainlyâ€ is an enthusiastic way to tell a coworker or customer that your help is guaranteed and wasnâ€™t an inconvenience to youâ€”you were glad to help them out. [11] X Research source Them : â€œThank you so much for bringing us extra pillows!â€ You : â€œCertainly! Weâ€™re here to make your stay with us as comfortable as possible.â€

steps.title: â€œYou are very welcome.â€
steps.content: â€œYou are very welcome.â€ To make a regular â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ sound a bit more formal or professional, add a modifier like â€œveryâ€ to emphasize your appreciation for someoneâ€™s gratitude and express your enjoyment in helping them. For instance, you can say â€œYou are so welcome, â€œYou are most welcome,â€ or â€œYou are quite welcome.â€ [12] X Research source Them : â€œThank you so much for coming to my classroom and talking to my students about your career. Lots of my students want to be biologists now!â€ You : â€œYou are very welcome. Iâ€™m always happy to talk about my job and get people interested in biology.â€

steps.title: â€œNot at all.â€
steps.content: â€œNot at all.â€ For a more formal alternative to â€œDonâ€™t mention itâ€ or â€œIt was nothing,â€ say â€œNot at all.â€ Like those phrases, â€œNot at allâ€ is a friendly and polite way to let people know that what you helped them with doesnâ€™t require their thanks. It also reassures them that you werenâ€™t burdened or inconvenienced by doing them a favor. [13] X Research source Them : â€œIâ€™m so grateful for your advice. You really helped us get started on the project.â€ You : â€œNot at all! Let me know if thereâ€™s anything else you might need help with.â€

steps.title: â€œNo thanks are necessary.â€
steps.content: â€œNo thanks are necessary.â€ â€œNo thanks are necessaryâ€ is a similar polite phrase to â€œNot at all.â€ It also communicates to colleagues, clients, and customers that their gratitude for your help really isnâ€™t necessary because what you did didnâ€™t inconvenience you or take time out of your busy day. In other words, helping them out wasnâ€™t a big deal. [14] X Research source Them : â€œThank you again for letting me borrow your projector. The meeting wouldâ€™ve been a disaster without it!â€ You : â€œNo thanks are necessary! Youâ€™re welcome to use it anytime you need.â€

steps.title: â€œI appreciate your thanks.â€
steps.content: â€œI appreciate your thanks.â€ Use this polite alternative to â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ when a colleague, client, or person you donâ€™t know very well thanks you for your kindness or helping them with a favor. This is a thoughtful way to acknowledge their gratitude and say that you are grateful to be able to help them out, too. Them : â€œThank you so much for letting us book a last-minute reservation at your restaurant. We know how busy you must be and we really appreciate it.â€ You : â€œI appreciate your thanks. Thatâ€™s very kind of you.â€

steps.title: â€œLet me know if thereâ€™s anything else I can do to help.â€
steps.content: â€œLet me know if thereâ€™s anything else I can do to help.â€ After you say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ to a customer or colleague that you helped, follow it up with an offer to assist them again in the future. Saying â€œLet me know if thereâ€™s anything else I can do to helpâ€ is a thoughtful gesture that lets someone know that you were happy to help them out and are willing to do it again. Them : â€œThank you again for sending over the project updates.â€ You : â€œOf course, Iâ€™m happy to assist. Let me know if thereâ€™s anything else I can do to help you.â€

steps.title: â€œThe pleasure is all mine.â€
steps.content: â€œThe pleasure is all mine.â€ Let your partner, friend, or family member know that thereâ€™s nothing you love more than giving them a gift, showing them kindness, or helping them out. This shows your loved ones that supporting them isnâ€™t a burden or bothersome. Instead, it brings you immense joy and fulfillment. Them : â€œI canâ€™t thank you enough for surprising me for my birthday! You are so thoughtful.â€ You : â€œThe pleasure is all mine. I love seeing you happy.â€

steps.title: â€œOf course, I am always here for you.â€
steps.content: â€œOf course, I am always here for you.â€ When a loved one gives you a heartfelt and thoughtful thank you, let them know that they can always count on you to help them. This is an especially sweet phrase if they feel guilty asking you for a favor or were worried about burdening you with an issue. Them : â€œI was nervous about playing the guitar in the show, but you being there put me at ease. Thank you again for coming!â€ You : â€œOf course, I am always here for you. Plus, I love to hear you play.â€

steps.title: â€œDonâ€™t worry about it, Iâ€™ve got you.â€
steps.content: â€œDonâ€™t worry about it, Iâ€™ve got you.â€ This warm and loving phrase is a great alternative to â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ when a loved one is thanking you for being there for them in a big way. Even if they asked you for a large favor or needed a lot of help, this communicates that they can never ask too much from youâ€”youâ€™ll never feel inconvenienced for supporting them. Them : â€œIâ€™m so grateful that you stayed over after my breakup. Just having you there made me feel less alone. I donâ€™t know what Iâ€™d do without you!â€ You : â€œDonâ€™t worry about it, Iâ€™ve got you. Iâ€™m here for you through the good and the bad.â€

steps.title: â€œIâ€™m so glad I could help.â€
steps.content: â€œIâ€™m so glad I could help.â€ Use this thoughtful expression when a friend or family member thanks you for doing something you wanted to help them with. This expresses your genuine joy for getting to help them and shows them that you appreciate their gratitude. [15] X Research source Them : â€œThank you for letting me borrow your truck! The move went great thanks to your help.â€ You : â€œIâ€™m so glad I could help!â€

steps.title: â€œItâ€™s no trouble at all.â€
steps.content: â€œItâ€™s no trouble at all.â€ â€œItâ€™s no trouble at allâ€ is a sweet alternative to â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ when you want to let a loved one know that the help they needed or favor they asked for wasnâ€™t an imposition. This phrase can help them feel better for asking you for help and show them that you enjoy being there for them. Them : â€œI am so grateful that you came so far out of your way to help us look for our dog Lucy. Weâ€™re so lucky that you were here to find her!â€ You : â€œIt was no trouble at all. Iâ€™m glad I could help bring her back home.â€

steps.title: â€œKnowing that I helped you is all the thanks I need.â€
steps.content: â€œKnowing that I helped you is all the thanks I need.â€ Use this phrase when you did something for a loved one out of the kindness of your heart and didnâ€™t even expect a thank you from them. This tells them that helping them out or making them smile was actually a gift to you. In other words, you love them and just want them to be happy. [16] X Research source Them : â€œThank you so much for talking to your boss and putting in a good word for me. I got the job! I canâ€™t thank you enough.â€ You : â€œKnowing that I helped you is all the thanks I need. I canâ€™t wait to be coworkers!â€

steps.title: Use silly phrases to liven up a â€œyouâ€™re welcomeâ€ to friends and family.
steps.content: Use silly phrases to liven up a â€œyouâ€™re welcomeâ€ to friends and family. When someone you know very well thanks you for helping them out or giving them a gift, itâ€™s appropriate to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in a funny way. These humorous phrases make it clear that you were glad to support them and werenâ€™t inconvenienced by helping them, while still showing appreciation for their gratitude. Below are just some examplesâ€”feel free to get creative with your â€œYouâ€™re welcome!â€ â€œYour wish is my command.â€ â€œIt was nothingâ€¦unless you want to buy me ice cream.â€ â€œI accept cash, check, or PayPal.â€ â€œOh, stop it! Youâ€™re making me blush.â€ â€œI am happy to serve.â€ â€œPlease mention it.â€ â€œItâ€™s okay, you can say that Iâ€™m the best ever. I donâ€™t mind.â€ â€œNo worries! Except now you owe me a favor.â€ â€œWell, thatâ€™s my good deed for the year.â€ â€œIâ€™ll be sending you an invoice in the morning.â€ â€œSo I guess weâ€™re even for that time I got you in troubleâ€¦â€ â€œJust put it on my tab.â€ â€œDonâ€™t mention it. Seriouslyâ€¦donâ€™t.â€ â€œIt was no problem at all, for the most part.â€ â€œIt is an honor, your Majesty.â€

steps.content: Spanish: â€œDe nadaâ€ or â€œNo hay de quÃ©.â€ The most common way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in Spanish is â€œDe nada,â€ which roughly translates to â€œItâ€™s nothing.â€ For a slightly more polite and formal alternative, say â€œNo hay de quÃ©,â€ which loosely means, â€œThereâ€™s nothing to thank me for.â€ [17] X Research source â€œDe nadaâ€ is pronounced deh nah-dah . â€œNo hay de quÃ©â€ is pronounced noh ay deh keh .

steps.content: Portuguese: â€œDe nadaâ€ or â€œNÃ£o tem de quÃª." Like in Spanish, the most popular and casual way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in Portuguese is â€œDe nada.â€ If youâ€™re in a more formal situation, say â€œNÃ£o tem de quÃª," which roughly means â€œThereâ€™s nothing to thank me for.â€ [18] X Research source â€œDe nadaâ€ is pronounced dee nah-dah . â€œNÃ£o tem de quÃª" is pronounced nah-oomm tah-eehm the queh .

steps.title: Italian: â€œPregoâ€ or â€œDi niente.â€
steps.content: Italian: â€œPregoâ€ or â€œDi niente.â€ The most common way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in Italian is â€œPrego,â€ which literally translates to â€œI pray.â€ A more casual way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ is â€œDi niente,â€ which means â€œItâ€™s nothing.â€ [19] X Research source â€œPregoâ€ is pronounced pray-goh . â€œDi nienteâ€ is pronounced dee nee-yehn-teh .

steps.content: French: â€œâ€‹â€‹De rienâ€ or â€œJe vous en prie.â€ In French, â€œâ€‹â€‹De rienâ€ is the casual and most popular way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcome,â€ which means something like â€œItâ€™s nothing.â€ To be polite in more formal situations, say â€œJe vous en prie,â€ which literally translates to â€œI beg you of it.â€ [20] X Research source â€œâ€‹â€‹De rienâ€ is pronounced duh ree-ehn . â€œJe vous en prieâ€ is pronounced zheh vooz-ahng pree .

steps.title: German: â€œBitteâ€ or â€œGern geschehen.â€
steps.content: German: â€œBitteâ€ or â€œGern geschehen.â€ In Germany, the casual way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ is â€œBitte,â€ which literally means â€œPlease.â€ In more formal situations or talking to someone you donâ€™t know well, say â€œGern geschehen,â€ which loosely translates to â€œMy pleasure.â€ [21] X Research source â€œBitteâ€ is pronounced biht-uh . â€œGern geschehenâ€ is pronounced gehrn geh-sheh-ehn .

To say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in Mandarin Chinese , say â€œä¸å®¢æ°”â€ (â€œbÃº kÃ¨ qÃ¬â€), which means something like â€œDonâ€™t mention it.â€ You can also say â€œä¸ç”¨è°¢â€ (â€œbÃº yÃ²ng xiÃ¨â€), which roughly translates to â€œThereâ€™s no need to thank me.â€ [22] X Research source â€œä¸å®¢æ°”â€ (â€œbÃº kÃ¨ qÃ¬â€) is pronounced boo kuh chee . â€œä¸ç”¨è°¢â€ (â€œbÃº yÃ²ng xiÃ¨â€) is pronounced boo yong shee-e .

One of the most common ways to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in Japanese is â€œã©ã†ã„ãŸã—ã¾ã—ã¦â€ (â€œdou itashi mashiteâ€), which literally translates to â€œHow can I help you?â€ In more casual situations, say â€œã„ãˆã„ãˆâ€ (â€œieieâ€), which roughly means â€œNo worries.â€ [23] X Research source â€œã©ã†ã„ãŸã—ã¾ã—ã¦â€ (â€œdou itashi mashiteâ€) is pronounced doh ee-tah-shee mah-she-teh . â€œã„ãˆã„ãˆâ€ (â€œieieâ€) is pronounced ee-yeh ee-yeh .

The most common way to say â€œYouâ€™re welcomeâ€ in Korean is â€œì•„ë‹ˆì—ìš”â€ (â€œaniaeyoâ€), which loosely means â€œNot at all.â€ A slightly more formal and polite alternative is â€œê´œì°®ì•„ìš”â€ (â€œgwaenchanayoâ€), which means something like â€œNo problem.â€ [24] X Research source â€œì•„ë‹ˆì—ìš”â€ (â€œaniaeyoâ€) is pronounced ah-nee-ae-yo . â€œê´œì°®ì•„ìš”â€ (â€œgwaenchanayoâ€) is pronounced gwaen-chahn-ah-yoh .
